Coming With The Family

Through other People,

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Coming with the family

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad Through other People, Reading About it)
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Not very much.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? Family and group.

13. What means of transportation did you use? A couch hocked unto a freight train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) One incident while going through Nakaki, a man coming through the couch with an open knife in his hand looking for another man that had been and killed. We came from and had arrested him and put him in jail. Indians until we were in Canada we did not meet with Indians until we were in Canada.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? In section house in Macoun

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Went out to the farm with Dad, Mother and sisters.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Moose Jaw, Weyburn, Halibute, Medale, Estevan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? Stayed at home with my parent 25, working on land working in millenary store.

   Quite often.

    Mr. Victor Peterson, Jan. 29th, 1907, Estevan

    Parents 5 sisters, April 1903
    Macoun
    Brother 1907 middle 1908, Sister 1909

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
    The coming out to the farm. Dad had forgotten to take the saw along out to the farm. Dad had stove pipe, so had to push in the window down and pull the pipe through the window. Shortly after we came, started raining. The roof of the house was only covered with tar paper and had to put pots and pans to catch the water. Pergamene and put up an umbrella to keep the rain off us.

24. Did you have school in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)
    Yes, we attended church, which was held in the dining room of the house. We used to go out to visit friends as often as we could, walking or horse and buggy, walked on ball games, went to dances, went to picnics in groups by horse and buggy.

you quite a bit of changes, less in proportion

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
   Yes, provided up there homestead and moved out.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
   Not too many.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
   Held office as telephone agent from 1920 to 1945 in Halldale. From 1945 to 1955 in Middale. Was active member of Halldale Homemakers Club from 1937 to 1945. Also member of Halldale United Church Hall and from 1920 to 1945.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "First" to have or do something in the district, mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
   My husband had the first threshing machine in our district.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
   Halldale got its name from two men, Halldale Station, Great Lakes Wright, but the two together Halldale. Halldale School from the Town Post Office from the town hall. Monsen's Grave from Mr. Monsen who homesteaded that land. The grave was also Everdell Grove from Mr. Swall who homesteaded that land. Both farmers, both about 1905.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Poveshull there homesteaded and moved out.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Yes,

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I held office as telephone agent from 1920 to 1945 in Hardin County, Illinois. I was active member of Hardin County United Church of Christ.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "First" to have or do something in the district combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My husband had the first threading machine in our district.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Hardin got its name from the town's founder, Mr. Hardin. The town was named after the first settlers, Mr. Hardin and Mr. Smith. They came from the town of Hardin, Illinois. Mr. Hardin was a man named Mr. Hardin who homesteaded land near the town. Mr. Hardin was also a member of the Hardin County United Church of Christ.
